page.lettertext:
fol.175r
May it please yo
r
good L. Her
Ma
ties
letter to
the
states
of
e 23 of
e last, w
t
an other from
yo
r
L. of
e 24 of
e same, came no sooner
unto me then two daies agoe. They were
brought unto me hither, by
e old Englishe post,
whiche was lately w
t
yo
r
L. who receaved
them, he saieth, about 4 daies before, of one
George Halle
S
r
Francis Veres
servant, to whome
they were delivered, as
e post had understood,
by a man of
S
r
Thomas Shirley
. There
were tw o thinges noted by yo
r
L. in that letter
whiche I writte
e 15 of July, That I dispat-
ched it before I had
e answear of
e states,
whome first it had bin fitte I should have
earnestly urged, to take some present resolu-
tion: and that in
e letter, w
ch
her Hig
nes
writte
unto
e states, I coneaved a further scruple,
then
e letter gave occasion. I beseeche
yo
r
L. for the first, to give me so muche cre-
dit, that I did my duty thorowly, in requi-
ring their answear: as I doe alwaies
e like,
in affaires of any moment, though I happen
to omitte to signifie suche pointes. For I pre-
sented her Hig
nes
letter
e 14 of
e forsaid mo-
neth, and I sent yo
w
their answear w
t
in two
daies after: w
ch
I doe seeldome gette so soone,
but w
t
great importunitie. For they say they
are a multitude, and in maters of importance
they can not so resolve, as her Ma
tie
may alone.
And as for writing before,
at I receaved their
answear, when I could not have it presently,
fol.175v
nor no certaintie otherwise, when they would
exhibit it, I thought I should doe best for con-
tenting yo
r
L. to advertise w
t
e soonest howe
I had proceeded, and w
at
I thought of their pur-
pose, and yet still to goe forward in soliciting
their answear, w
ch
I sent
e next day after.
I hope yo
r
L. is persuaded,
at for
mine owne understanding I was not troubled
w
t
any scruple in her Ma
ties
letter. For I knewe
directly what was meant, by those
at I receaved,
and so I signified sufficiently in my publike dea-
ling w
t
e states. But being heere where I sawe
howe muche it went against their mindes, and
finding
at
e letter was not altogether peremptory,
but indited in suche wordes, as seemed in the rea-
ding to include a kinde of libertie, I hope yo
r
L.
will conceave
at
e maner of my suspition, in
respect of their construction, was not founded
upon nothing. True it is
at her Ma
tie
writte
enough, both
at
that time and before, whereby they
might perceave,
at her meaning was no other,
but to send for
e companies: yet it was not in
the letter in
at resolut maner, as if she would
not be refused, or as her Hig
nes
heeretofore in
suche other her demaundes hath signified ex-
pressely. And although it was sufficient
that I declared it unto them, because they
were referred to
e pointes of my instructions,
yet knowing they were inclined to stand upon
denial, I could not but imagine,
at they would
helpe them selves in every sort, w
t
any wordes of
fol.176r
apparance of advantage unto them. And so it
proved by their answear. I did
yesterday deliver her Ma
ties
letter, w
ch
they thought
very strange to come so slowly to their handes,
for
at there have bin many passages,
then
sins
the
letter was written, and divers letters heere re-
ceaved, about 18 daies before,
at were dated
in
London
about
e self same time. I doe assure
yo
r
L.
e slacknes of suche messengers, w
ch
hap-
neth very often, doth make me leese
e opportuni-
ties, of effecting suche thinges as her Ma
tie
re-
quireth. For heere they gaine by suche meanes
a great deale of time, and devise howe to crosse
her Ma
ties
intent, w
ch
might passe perhaps at
first w
t
lesse opposition. What answear
ei
will make, I can not learne, nor conjecture.
For although I have bin instant in requiring it
of them, they say they must have time to delibe-
rat w
t
themselves: and I finde them alwaies
one in their unwilling disposition.
Yo
r
L. last unto me was written
e 28 of
July, and I receaved it heere
e 11 of this p
nt
,
returning an answear
e very same day.
The occurrences of
Coevoerden
doe better every
day, and
e place, there is no doubt, will be
o
rs
very shortly, unles
e Enemie make a head.
w
ch
,
e bruite is, he doth purpose. For the
speeche is given out,
at there are in readines
to passe
e Rhine 22 Enseignes of Spaniardes,
16 Dutche, and 6 of Wallons, w
t
400 horse;
w
ch
are thought will amount, w
t
e troupes of
Verdugo
, to 5000 men: wherof we looke every
houre to be better informed.
Count Philip
fol.176v
of Nassau is returned out of France, w
t
all his
Captaines and companies. They are judged at
e lest to be 1300 men.
Mons
r
Bu-
zenval
hath bin this morning w
t
e states, with
letters from
e
King,
to pray
e loane of so muche
mony, as may suffice for 4 monethes, to inter-
tene 3000 foote: and w
t
all to spare him three
of their greater shippes of warre, and two pinaces
to lie in
e Sene for
e space of 3 monethes.
He hath had no other answear, but
at
e Pro-
vinces must be moved. Howbeit I am per-
suaded, they will take some present order for
sending
e shippes: and will procure w
t
good speed,
a competent summe of mony:
And thus for this
present I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. Au
g
19 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
